newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japan refiners step up efforts to restructure.
newsitem.headline: Japan refiners step up efforts to restructure.

text.p: The failure of plunging gasoline prices to rebound has forced Japanese oil refiners to step up efforts to slim down, industry sources said on Friday.
"Refiners increasingly need to cut costs as gasoline retail prices are not recovering," said Takashi Kawai, an analyst with the private Nikko Research Center.
"Refiners are very puzzled," Kawai said.
Showa Shell Sekiyu KK, an oil refiner and distributor owned 50 percent by the Royal Dutch/Shell Group, said it would hasten plans to slash distribution costs.
It said it would aim to trim its distribution costs by 13 billion yen ($118 million) by 2000, moving forward an earlier target date by four years.
The efforts to cut distribution costs are part of a plan Showa Shell unveiled earlier this year aimed at improving profits by 40 billion yen ($363 million) by the year 2000.
"We will take all possible measures to cut costs," a spokesman for Showa Shell said.
Refiners have been struggling to cut costs as revenue from gasoline sales, previously a pillar of their income, has tumbled together with plunging retail prices.
In the past two years, in the run up to deregulation in oil product imports this April, gasoline retail prices nose-dived as gasoline stations raced to cut prices fearing floods of cheap imports.
Refiners lost their monopoly on imports of items such as gasoline, kerosene and gas oil after the deregulation.
In order to combat imports, major refiners introduced a new wholesale pricing system this year which reflects international oil product prices as well as crude prices and currency rates.
With the implentation of the new system, refiners had expected gasoline retail prices to pick up in regions where they had fallen too far.
However, since April, retail prices have weakened despite rising wholesale prices.
During the period from April to August, refiners raised their wholesale prices by about 1.5 yen per litre reflecting higher crude prices and a weaker yen against the dollar.
But during the same period retail prices dropped by about 2 yen to a national average of 105 yen ($0.95) per litre.
Tax, which is fully passed on to the consumer, accounts for more than half of the retail price.
In September 1995, the average national gasoline retail price was 112 yen (about $1), down 8 yen from a year earlier, according to Japan's Oil Information Service Centre.
The weak market environment has forced the refiners to forge cooperation agreements with each other.
The industry was stunned last year when arch-rivals Nippon Oil Co Ltd and Idemitsu Kosan Co Ltd, Japan's top two oil firms, announced plans to cooperate.
On Friday, Nippon Oil and Idemitsu Kosan said they had started supplying fuel oil to each other.
The agreement should save Nippon Oil about 1 billion yen ($9 million) in the year to next March, Nippon Oil said.
Persistent rumours that stronger ties between Nippon Oil and Idemitsu would eventually lead to a merger, have been denied by both companies.
Analysts said rather than a complete merger, Nippon Oil and Idemitsu may eventually jointly manage distribution. ($1=110)
